name: Cat Eye Syndrome
description: Cat Eye Syndrome (CES) is a rare genetic disorder caused by a partial trisomy or tetrasomy of chromosome 22, specifically involving the 22pter-q11 region. It is characterized by a wide range of congenital malformations, most commonly affecting the eyes (coloboma), ears, heart, and kidneys. The severity of symptoms varies greatly among affected individuals.
inheritance: Most cases are sporadic (de novo). Rarely, inherited from a parent with a balanced translocation or inversion involving chromosome 22.
symptoms: Anal atresia with or without fistula
Heart defects (e.g., total anomalous pulmonary venous return)
prognosis: The prognosis varies depending on the severity of the malformations and associated complications. Some individuals may have mild symptoms and a normal life expectancy, while others with severe heart or kidney defects may have a poorer prognosis.
lifeExpectancy: Variable, depending on the severity of associated malformations. Individuals with mild symptoms can have a normal life expectancy.
diagnosticMethods: Chromosome analysis (karyotyping) to detect partial trisomy/tetrasomy 22
Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) to confirm the presence of extra 22pter-q11 material
Renal ultrasound to assess kidney abnormalities

treatmentOptions.name: Hearing aids or cochlear implants for hearing loss
Special education and developmental therapies for intellectual disability
Corrective lenses or surgery for vision problems

patientOrganizations.name: Unique - Understanding Rare Chromosome and Gene Disorders

eli5Summary: Imagine your body has instructions to build itself, like a Lego set. Cat Eye Syndrome happens when there's an extra little piece of one of the instructions (chromosome 22). This extra piece can cause problems with how your eyes, ears, heart, and other body parts are built, making them a little different.
clinicalSummary: Cat Eye Syndrome (CES) is a rare, multiple congenital anomaly syndrome resulting from partial trisomy or tetrasomy of chromosome 22pter-q11. The duplicated region contains the *CECR1* gene (also known as *ADA2*), among others. The clinical phenotype is highly variable, ranging from individuals with minimal clinical findings to those with severe, life-threatening malformations. The most consistent features include coloboma of the iris (often giving the appearance of a 'cat eye'), anal atresia with or without fistula, preauricular skin tags or pits, and downslanting palpebral fissures. Other common features include congenital heart defects (especially total anomalous pulmonary venous return), renal anomalies, skeletal abnormalities, and mild to moderate intellectual disability. Diagnosis is typically made through chromosomal analysis (karyotyping, FISH, or CMA). Management is focused on addressing the specific malformations present in each individual through surgical correction, supportive care, and developmental therapies. Genetic counseling is essential for families with an affected individual.
historicalBackground: Cat Eye Syndrome was first described in the medical literature in the late 1960s. The term 'Cat Eye Syndrome' was coined due to the characteristic iris coloboma observed in many affected individuals. The underlying genetic cause, involving partial trisomy/tetrasomy of chromosome 22, was later identified through advancements in cytogenetic techniques.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Identification of CECR1/ADA2 as a key gene in Cat Eye Syndrome
recentBreakthroughs.description: Research has highlighted the role of the CECR1/ADA2 gene, located in the critical region of chromosome 22q11, in the pathogenesis of Cat Eye Syndrome. Mutations in this gene have been linked to vasculopathy and inflammation, providing insights into the diverse clinical manifestations of the syndrome.
